title: Does consciousness exist independent of human beings? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is still a matter of intense scientific (and philosophical debate), but it clearly depends on what you mean by consciousness. Various ape species (of which we seem to be close relatives) seem fairly provably to share the ability to know they are alive, recognize a ‘self’ and that the self is mortal. But also clearly they see the world quite differently from us in many ways, probably including their vision of ‘self.’ So are they possessors of ‘consciousness’ or not? Depends on what you feel has to be included in the definition of that word. They clearly have some form of it, but not exactly ours. Of course this opens the door to ask whether machines will attain consciousness and what the definition will look like when they are much more like us than at present… in some respects… or in all respects. Again, likely a different, perhaps enhanced form of consciousness and we won’t be able to retain our belief that we’re at the top of the heap. But, even so, will that reduce our feelings of well-being. We will feel humiliated, short-changed, will we try to live up to the new, higher level? All interesting, but unresolvable questions… for now.

A thing or quality comes into existence only after it is discovered by a discoverer. A discovery becomes collective perception when it is accepted by all or most in a class. For instance humans accept that mango is an edible fruit and that's our collective perception or discovery. The question of existence of a thing is not valid for a thing which is not discovered. Both the discoverer and the dicovered object together define the existence of that particular object in terms of a totality of characteristics it is discovered to have. Note the use of phrase 'totality of characteristics'. Humans discover mango to be an edible fruit but tigers do not. Thus consciousness will cease to exist in the totality of characteristics that humans cognise it to have once humans become extinct. I urge you again to underline the phrase 'totality of characteristics'. The question whether consciousness will still exist in a manner humans have not cognised it is an invalid question.

Consciousness is the body’s navigational system; it consists of the act of paying attention to signals for relevance to survival. All animals are conscious of their surroundings. Some animals appear to be conscious of themselves to some extent. Humans too but we have this added layer of thoughts about everything so our little bit of self awareness can be thought about in ways that perhaps no other animal does, and that may be why some think only humans are conscious of themselves. But you asked about consciousness, not self consciousness / self awareness.

Although some in the science community may debate this to the end of time, most if not all animals have a degree and form of consciousness. Thus yes, consciousness does exist independant of human beings.
